TRX Functional Training

Movement re-training, core stability, and functional strength—customized for your body.

Why I Use TRX in My Physical Therapy Approach

TRX is one of the most versatile tools I use in my Midtown Manhattan studio near Penn Station. Unlike machines or heavy weights, TRX uses your own bodyweight to build **movement control, core stability, balance, and strength** in a way that translates directly into real-life movement.

Many people who come to see me don’t just need soft-tissue work—they need their muscles, joints, and nervous system to work together again. TRX helps rebuild that coordination safely and effectively. It is especially useful when combined with technologies like shockwave therapy, TECAR therapy, Class 4 laser, or Compex EMS.

How TRX Helps You Move Better

  • Bodyweight resistance: Uses gravity and your own strength to improve control without overloading joints.
  • Instability training: Challenges your core and stabilizers in every exercise.
  • Movement pattern focus: Helps retrain squatting, hinging, pulling, pushing, lunging, and rotational tasks.
  • Adjustable difficulty: Progression is simple—walk your feet forward/back to change intensity.

What I Use TRX Training For

  • Rebuilding core stability after pain or prolonged sitting
  • Improving hip and glute activation
  • Shoulder stability work for pressing and overhead movement
  • Single-leg control for runners and athletes
  • Correcting asymmetry and compensations
  • Posture and movement re-education
  • Low-impact strengthening for people returning to exercise

Examples of TRX Exercises I Use

  • TRX Rows — building shoulder retraction and postural control
  • TRX Squats / Assisted Pistol Squats — improving lower-body mechanics
  • TRX Fallouts / Rollouts — advanced core stability without back strain
  • TRX Hip Hinge Work — better glute activation and hinge patterning
  • TRX Single-leg Balance Drills — training foot, knee, and hip coordination
  • TRX Plank Variations — anti-rotation and anti-extension core control

What Does TRX Training Feel Like?

TRX is adjustable and joint-friendly. You control the intensity simply by changing your body angle, so it’s suitable for beginners and advanced movers. Most people are surprised at how challenging—and safe—it feels when used with proper coaching and individualized cues.

If you want to improve the way you move—not just treat pain—TRX is one of the most effective tools I use. I’ll guide you through a plan that matches your strength level and movement goals.
